content: +++http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278 Administration open to taxing health benefits Proposal problematic for Obama as he denounced similar one in campaign Video Obama holds health care summit March 5: President Obama turns his focus to health care, holding a summit at the White House to come up with an overhaul of the nation’s health care system. NBC’s John Yang reports. Today show Video A ray of hope seen in stimulus plan March 13: President Barack Obama said Friday his programs are laying a foundation for economic growth, while his chief advisers suggested there is evidence the stimulus plan is starting to have an impact. Nightly News Administration Is Open to Taxing Health Benefits A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five Split on Recession Cure, Leaders Try 3 Approaches President Promises to Bolster Food Safety By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear updated 5:06 a.m. ET, Sun., March. 15, 2009 WASHINGTON - The Obama administration is signaling to Congress that the president could support taxing some employee health benefits, as several influential lawmakers and many economists favor, to help pay for overhauling the health care system. The proposal is politically problematic for President Obama, however, since it is similar to one he denounced in the presidential campaign as “the largest middle-class tax increase in history.” Most Americans with insurance get it from their employers, and taxing workers for the benefit is opposed by union leaders and some businesses. In television advertisements last fall, Mr. Obama criticized his Republican rival for the presidency, Senator John McCain of Arizona, for proposing to tax all employer-provided health benefits. The benefits have long been tax-free, regardless of how generous they are or how much an employee earns. The advertisements did not point out that Mr. McCain, in exchange, wanted to give all families a tax credit to subsidize the purchase of coverage. Story continues below ↓ -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- advertisement | your ad here -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- At the time, even some Obama supporters said privately that he might come to regret his position if he won the election; in effect, they said, he was potentially giving up an important option to help finance his ambitious health care agenda to reduce medical costs and to expand coverage to the 46 million uninsured Americans. Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. Click for related content NYT: Obama on spot as rulings aid gay partners NYT: Obama's court nominees focus of speculation NYT: A zealous watchman to follow the money They, like other proponents, cite evidence that tax-free benefits encourage what Mr. McCain called “gold-plated” policies, resulting in inefficient and costly demands for health care and pressure on employers to hold down workers’ pay as insurance expenses rise. And, they say, the policy discriminates against those — many of whom are low-income workers — who do not have employer-provided coverage. When Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, advocated taxing benefits at a recent hearing of the Finance Committee, which he leads, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner assured him that the administration was open to all ideas from Congress. Mr. Geithner did, however, allude to the position that Mr. Obama had taken as a candidate. More from NYTimes.com A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five No Clear Accord on Stimulus by Top 20 Nations President Promises to Bolster Food Safety Finding Messages in a Blueprint External links The administration’s receptivity to the idea is owed partly to the advocacy of Mr. Baucus, whose committee has jurisdiction over tax policy and health programs, and to support from Republicans. There is less enthusiasm among Democrats in the House, though the health debate is at an early stage and no comprehensive plans are on the table. Also, Mr. Obama’s own idea for raising revenues for health care — limiting the income tax deductions that the most affluent taxpayers claim — has run into opposition not only from Mr. Baucus but also from his counterpart in the House, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Obama’s proposed limit on deductions would raise an estimated $318 billion over 10 years, or half of his proposed “health care reserve fund.” That is a fraction of the revenues that could be raised from taxing employer-provided health benefits. In the campaign, Mr. McCain estimated that taxing all health benefits would raise $3.6 trillion over a decade — “a multitrillion-dollar tax hike,” one Obama advertisement said. The Congressional Budget Office says that including health benefits in taxable income could mean $246 billion in additional revenue for a single year. Stopping short of full taxation, as Mr. Baucus and others suggest, would mean less new revenue. The latest government figures, for 2007, show that 70 percent of the 253 million people with health insurance received at least some of their coverage through employers. Employment-based insurance covers three-fifths of the population under 65.

content: When your sources of information are limited, you don't have much access to facts. This has been discussed for months. Max Baucus of Montana introduced a policy paper back in December that suggested capping tax breaks for health insurance premiums. These breaks would be based on income or the value of the benefits. This is basically the model for what Obama proposes. The President and Veep have been leaning in this direction for some time now, and they and the Dems in Congress are likely coming to some sort of compromise. As a person whose spouse paid into a national health care system (Germany) with her taxes, it doesn't seem a problem to me; it actually makes sense, as there aren't too many other ways to generate the revenues necessary to create the program the President is advocating. What will hopefully happen is that, as other programs are reduced and the tax burden is reorganized, there may still be a reduction in what you pay in taxes overall, but health care will simply be one of those things your taxes pay for.

content: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by mcgreer: When your sources of information are limited, you don't have much access to facts. This has been discussed for months. Max Baucus of Montana introduced a policy paper back in December that suggested capping tax breaks for health insurance premiums. These breaks would be based on income or the value of the benefits. This is basically the model for what Obama proposes. The President and Veep have been leaning in this direction for some time now, and they and the Dems in Congress are likely coming to some sort of compromise. As a person whose spouse paid into a national health care system (Germany) with her taxes, it doesn't seem a problem to me; it actually makes sense, as there aren't too many other ways to generate the revenues necessary to create the program the President is advocating. What will hopefully happen is that, as other programs are reduced and the tax burden is reorganized, there may still be a reduction in what you pay in taxes overall, but health care will simply be one of those things your taxes pay for. For some time? Like since..1-20-09? Or since the DAY AFTER he claimed he would never do this? You've stated what you think will "hopefully" happen. Let me tell you what will happen if this idea is turned into law: Every single middle class person will be taxed into the lower class. There will be NO middle class.. Just a bunch of under educated, under employeed people..all living in the same government built housing projects..all driving the same "green" car..all working for the same $4.75 an hour...all getting crappy health care. We won't be taxed that heavily. Now - this debate has gone on since during the campaign - and right after the election, Baucus introduced that policy paper I'm speaking of (read the actual paper here.). If you don't feel like doing that - and I suspect most here won't - here's a news item from The Hill, dated 12 November 2008, the date of the release of his plan: "Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus stepped to the forefront of the national debate over healthcare with a sweeping universal-coverage plan, pushing the issue to the top of the next Congress's agenda. 'In 2009, Congress must take up and act on meaningful health reform legislation that achieves coverage for all Americans while also addressing the underlying problems in our health system,' the Montana Democrat said in a policy paper released Wednesday. 'The urgency of this task has become undeniable.' Under the Montana Democrat's plan, all Americans would be required to hold a health insurance policy, going one step further than President-elect Barack Obama's plan. Individuals could keep their existing health plans or join a nationwide insurance pool to buy coverage, the price tag of which would be reduced with government subsidies. Insurers would not be allowed to discriminate based on pre-existing conditions, a centerpiece of Obama's plan..." "http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/baucus-unveils-sweeping-healthcare-plan-2008-11-12.html" Don't you guys get bored with seeing everything through a partisan political lens? There's a lot more going out here - and you miss the opportunity to get so much more information by doing such a thing. It's always the same old argument. That's tired. Ick...!

content: +++http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278 Administration open to taxing health benefits Proposal problematic for Obama as he denounced similar one in campaign Video Obama holds health care summit March 5: President Obama turns his focus to health care, holding a summit at the White House to come up with an overhaul of the nation’s health care system. NBC’s John Yang reports. Today show Video A ray of hope seen in stimulus plan March 13: President Barack Obama said Friday his programs are laying a foundation for economic growth, while his chief advisers suggested there is evidence the stimulus plan is starting to have an impact. Nightly News Administration Is Open to Taxing Health Benefits A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five Split on Recession Cure, Leaders Try 3 Approaches President Promises to Bolster Food Safety By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear updated 5:06 a.m. ET, Sun., March. 15, 2009 WASHINGTON - The Obama administration is signaling to Congress that the president could support taxing some employee health benefits, as several influential lawmakers and many economists favor, to help pay for overhauling the health care system. The proposal is politically problematic for President Obama, however, since it is similar to one he denounced in the presidential campaign as “the largest middle-class tax increase in history.” Most Americans with insurance get it from their employers, and taxing workers for the benefit is opposed by union leaders and some businesses. In television advertisements last fall, Mr. Obama criticized his Republican rival for the presidency, Senator John McCain of Arizona, for proposing to tax all employer-provided health benefits. The benefits have long been tax-free, regardless of how generous they are or how much an employee earns. The advertisements did not point out that Mr. McCain, in exchange, wanted to give all families a tax credit to subsidize the purchase of coverage. Story continues below ↓ -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- advertisement | your ad here -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- At the time, even some Obama supporters said privately that he might come to regret his position if he won the election; in effect, they said, he was potentially giving up an important option to help finance his ambitious health care agenda to reduce medical costs and to expand coverage to the 46 million uninsured Americans. Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. Click for related content NYT: Obama on spot as rulings aid gay partners NYT: Obama's court nominees focus of speculation NYT: A zealous watchman to follow the money They, like other proponents, cite evidence that tax-free benefits encourage what Mr. McCain called “gold-plated” policies, resulting in inefficient and costly demands for health care and pressure on employers to hold down workers’ pay as insurance expenses rise. And, they say, the policy discriminates against those — many of whom are low-income workers — who do not have employer-provided coverage. When Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, advocated taxing benefits at a recent hearing of the Finance Committee, which he leads, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner assured him that the administration was open to all ideas from Congress. Mr. Geithner did, however, allude to the position that Mr. Obama had taken as a candidate. More from NYTimes.com A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five No Clear Accord on Stimulus by Top 20 Nations President Promises to Bolster Food Safety Finding Messages in a Blueprint External links The administration’s receptivity to the idea is owed partly to the advocacy of Mr. Baucus, whose committee has jurisdiction over tax policy and health programs, and to support from Republicans. There is less enthusiasm among Democrats in the House, though the health debate is at an early stage and no comprehensive plans are on the table. Also, Mr. Obama’s own idea for raising revenues for health care — limiting the income tax deductions that the most affluent taxpayers claim — has run into opposition not only from Mr. Baucus but also from his counterpart in the House, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Obama’s proposed limit on deductions would raise an estimated $318 billion over 10 years, or half of his proposed “health care reserve fund.” That is a fraction of the revenues that could be raised from taxing employer-provided health benefits. In the campaign, Mr. McCain estimated that taxing all health benefits would raise $3.6 trillion over a decade — “a multitrillion-dollar tax hike,” one Obama advertisement said. The Congressional Budget Office says that including health benefits in taxable income could mean $246 billion in additional revenue for a single year. Stopping short of full taxation, as Mr. Baucus and others suggest, would mean less new revenue. The latest government figures, for 2007, show that 70 percent of the 253 million people with health insurance received at least some of their coverage through employers. Employment-based insurance covers three-fifths of the population under 65.

Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five Split on Recession Cure, Leaders Try 3 Approaches President Promises to Bolster Food Safety By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear updated 5:06 a.m. ET, Sun., March. 15, 2009 WASHINGTON - The Obama administration is signaling to Congress that the president could support taxing some employee health benefits, as several influential lawmakers and many economists favor, to help pay for overhauling the health care system. The proposal is politically problematic for President Obama, however, since it is similar to one he denounced in the presidential campaign as “the largest middle-class tax increase in history.” Most Americans with insurance get it from their employers, and taxing workers for the benefit is opposed by union leaders and some businesses. In television advertisements last fall, Mr. Obama criticized his Republican rival for the presidency, Senator John McCain of Arizona, for proposing to tax all employer-provided health benefits. The benefits have long been tax-free, regardless of how generous they are or how much an employee earns. The advertisements did not point out that Mr. McCain, in exchange, wanted to give all families a tax credit to subsidize the purchase of coverage. Story continues below ↓ -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- advertisement | your ad here -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- At the time, even some Obama supporters said privately that he might come to regret his position if he won the election; in effect, they said, he was potentially giving up an important option to help finance his ambitious health care agenda to reduce medical costs and to expand coverage to the 46 million uninsured Americans. Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. content: When your sources of information are limited, you don't have much access to facts. This has been discussed for months. Max Baucus of Montana introduced a policy paper back in December that suggested capping tax breaks for health insurance premiums. These breaks would be based on income or the value of the benefits. This is basically the model for what Obama proposes. The President and Veep have been leaning in this direction for some time now, and they and the Dems in Congress are likely coming to some sort of compromise. As a person whose spouse paid into a national health care system (Germany) with her taxes, it doesn't seem a problem to me; it actually makes sense, as there aren't too many other ways to generate the revenues necessary to create the program the President is advocating. What will hopefully happen is that, as other programs are reduced and the tax burden is reorganized, there may still be a reduction in what you pay in taxes overall, but health care will simply be one of those things your taxes pay for.

content: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by mcgreer: When your sources of information are limited, you don't have much access to facts. This has been discussed for months. Max Baucus of Montana introduced a policy paper back in December that suggested capping tax breaks for health insurance premiums. These breaks would be based on income or the value of the benefits. This is basically the model for what Obama proposes. The President and Veep have been leaning in this direction for some time now, and they and the Dems in Congress are likely coming to some sort of compromise. As a person whose spouse paid into a national health care system (Germany) with her taxes, it doesn't seem a problem to me; it actually makes sense, as there aren't too many other ways to generate the revenues necessary to create the program the President is advocating. What will hopefully happen is that, as other programs are reduced and the tax burden is reorganized, there may still be a reduction in what you pay in taxes overall, but health care will simply be one of those things your taxes pay for. For some time? Like since..1-20-09? Or since the DAY AFTER he claimed he would never do this? You've stated what you think will "hopefully" happen. Let me tell you what will happen if this idea is turned into law: Every single middle class person will be taxed into the lower class. There will be NO middle class.. Just a bunch of under educated, under employeed people..all living in the same government built housing projects..all driving the same "green" car..all working for the same $4.75 an hour...all getting crappy health care. We won't be taxed that heavily. Now - this debate has gone on since during the campaign - and right after the election, Baucus introduced that policy paper I'm speaking of (read the actual paper here.). If you don't feel like doing that - and I suspect most here won't - here's a news item from The Hill, dated 12 November 2008, the date of the release of his plan: "Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus stepped to the forefront of the national debate over healthcare with a sweeping universal-coverage plan, pushing the issue to the top of the next Congress's agenda. 'In 2009, Congress must take up and act on meaningful health reform legislation that achieves coverage for all Americans while also addressing the underlying problems in our health system,' the Montana Democrat said in a policy paper released Wednesday. 'The urgency of this task has become undeniable.' Under the Montana Democrat's plan, all Americans would be required to hold a health insurance policy, going one step further than President-elect Barack Obama's plan. Individuals could keep their existing health plans or join a nationwide insurance pool to buy coverage, the price tag of which would be reduced with government subsidies. Insurers would not be allowed to discriminate based on pre-existing conditions, a centerpiece of Obama's plan..." "http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/baucus-unveils-sweeping-healthcare-plan-2008-11-12.html" Don't you guys get bored with seeing everything through a partisan political lens? There's a lot more going out here - and you miss the opportunity to get so much more information by doing such a thing. It's always the same old argument. That's tired. Ick...!

content: +++http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278 Administration open to taxing health benefits Proposal problematic for Obama as he denounced similar one in campaign Video Obama holds health care summit March 5: President Obama turns his focus to health care, holding a summit at the White House to come up with an overhaul of the nation’s health care system. NBC’s John Yang reports. Today show Video A ray of hope seen in stimulus plan March 13: President Barack Obama said Friday his programs are laying a foundation for economic growth, while his chief advisers suggested there is evidence the stimulus plan is starting to have an impact. Nightly News Administration Is Open to Taxing Health Benefits A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five Split on Recession Cure, Leaders Try 3 Approaches President Promises to Bolster Food Safety By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear updated 5:06 a.m. ET, Sun., March. 15, 2009 WASHINGTON - The Obama administration is signaling to Congress that the president could support taxing some employee health benefits, as several influential lawmakers and many economists favor, to help pay for overhauling the health care system. The proposal is politically problematic for President Obama, however, since it is similar to one he denounced in the presidential campaign as “the largest middle-class tax increase in history.” Most Americans with insurance get it from their employers, and taxing workers for the benefit is opposed by union leaders and some businesses. In television advertisements last fall, Mr. Obama criticized his Republican rival for the presidency, Senator John McCain of Arizona, for proposing to tax all employer-provided health benefits. The benefits have long been tax-free, regardless of how generous they are or how much an employee earns. The advertisements did not point out that Mr. McCain, in exchange, wanted to give all families a tax credit to subsidize the purchase of coverage. Story continues below ↓ -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- advertisement | your ad here -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- At the time, even some Obama supporters said privately that he might come to regret his position if he won the election; in effect, they said, he was potentially giving up an important option to help finance his ambitious health care agenda to reduce medical costs and to expand coverage to the 46 million uninsured Americans. Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. Click for related content NYT: Obama on spot as rulings aid gay partners NYT: Obama's court nominees focus of speculation NYT: A zealous watchman to follow the money They, like other proponents, cite evidence that tax-free benefits encourage what Mr. McCain called “gold-plated” policies, resulting in inefficient and costly demands for health care and pressure on employers to hold down workers’ pay as insurance expenses rise. And, they say, the policy discriminates against those — many of whom are low-income workers — who do not have employer-provided coverage. When Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, advocated taxing benefits at a recent hearing of the Finance Committee, which he leads, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner assured him that the administration was open to all ideas from Congress. Mr. Geithner did, however, allude to the position that Mr. Obama had taken as a candidate. More from NYTimes.com A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five No Clear Accord on Stimulus by Top 20 Nations President Promises to Bolster Food Safety Finding Messages in a Blueprint External links The administration’s receptivity to the idea is owed partly to the advocacy of Mr. Baucus, whose committee has jurisdiction over tax policy and health programs, and to support from Republicans. There is less enthusiasm among Democrats in the House, though the health debate is at an early stage and no comprehensive plans are on the table. Also, Mr. Obama’s own idea for raising revenues for health care — limiting the income tax deductions that the most affluent taxpayers claim — has run into opposition not only from Mr. Baucus but also from his counterpart in the House, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Obama’s proposed limit on deductions would raise an estimated $318 billion over 10 years, or half of his proposed “health care reserve fund.” That is a fraction of the revenues that could be raised from taxing employer-provided health benefits. In the campaign, Mr. McCain estimated that taxing all health benefits would raise $3.6 trillion over a decade — “a multitrillion-dollar tax hike,” one Obama advertisement said. The Congressional Budget Office says that including health benefits in taxable income could mean $246 billion in additional revenue for a single year. Stopping short of full taxation, as Mr. Baucus and others suggest, would mean less new revenue. The latest government figures, for 2007, show that 70 percent of the 253 million people with health insurance received at least some of their coverage through employers. Employment-based insurance covers three-fifths of the population under 65.

At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. Click for related content NYT: Obama on spot as rulings aid gay partners NYT: Obama's court nominees focus of speculation NYT: A zealous watchman to follow the money They, like other proponents, cite evidence that tax-free benefits encourage what Mr. McCain called “gold-plated” policies, resulting in inefficient and costly demands for health care and pressure on employers to hold down workers’ pay as insurance expenses rise. And, they say, the policy discriminates against those — many of whom are low-income workers — who do not have employer-provided coverage. When Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, advocated taxing benefits at a recent hearing of the Finance Committee, which he leads, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner assured him that the administration was open to all ideas from Congress. Mr. Geithner did, however, allude to the position that Mr. Obama had taken as a candidate. More from NYTimes.com A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five No Clear Accord on Stimulus by Top 20 Nations President Promises to Bolster Food Safety Finding Messages in a Blueprint External links The administration’s receptivity to the idea is owed partly to the advocacy of Mr. Baucus, whose committee has jurisdiction over tax policy and health programs, and to support from Republicans. There is less enthusiasm among Democrats in the House, though the health debate is at an early stage and no comprehensive plans are on the table. Also, Mr. Obama’s own idea for raising revenues for health care — limiting the income tax deductions that the most affluent taxpayers claim — has run into opposition not only from Mr. Baucus but also from his counterpart in the House, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Obama’s proposed limit on deductions would raise an estimated $318 billion over 10 years, or half of his proposed “health care reserve fund.” That is a fraction of the revenues that could be raised from taxing employer-provided health benefits. In the campaign, Mr. McCain estimated that taxing all health benefits would raise $3.6 trillion over a decade — “a multitrillion-dollar tax hike,” one Obama advertisement said. The Congressional Budget Office says that including health benefits in taxable income could mean $246 billion in additional revenue for a single year. Stopping short of full taxation, as Mr. Baucus and others suggest, would mean less new revenue. The latest government figures, for 2007, show that 70 percent of the 253 million people with health insurance received at least some of their coverage through employers. Employment-based insurance covers three-fifths of the population under 65.

content: When your sources of information are limited, you don't have much access to facts. This has been discussed for months. Max Baucus of Montana introduced a policy paper back in December that suggested capping tax breaks for health insurance premiums. These breaks would be based on income or the value of the benefits. This is basically the model for what Obama proposes. The President and Veep have been leaning in this direction for some time now, and they and the Dems in Congress are likely coming to some sort of compromise. As a person whose spouse paid into a national health care system (Germany) with her taxes, it doesn't seem a problem to me; it actually makes sense, as there aren't too many other ways to generate the revenues necessary to create the program the President is advocating. What will hopefully happen is that, as other programs are reduced and the tax burden is reorganized, there may still be a reduction in what you pay in taxes overall, but health care will simply be one of those things your taxes pay for.

The President and Veep have been leaning in this direction for some time now, and they and the Dems in Congress are likely coming to some sort of compromise. As a person whose spouse paid into a national health care system (Germany) with her taxes, it doesn't seem a problem to me; it actually makes sense, as there aren't too many other ways to generate the revenues necessary to create the program the President is advocating. What will hopefully happen is that, as other programs are reduced and the tax burden is reorganized, there may still be a reduction in what you pay in taxes overall, but health care will simply be one of those things your taxes pay for. For some time? Like since..1-20-09? Or since the DAY AFTER he claimed he would never do this? You've stated what you think will "hopefully" happen. Let me tell you what will happen if this idea is turned into law: Every single middle class person will be taxed into the lower class. There will be NO middle class.. Just a bunch of under educated, under employeed people..all living in the same government built housing projects..all driving the same "green" car..all working for the same $4.75 an hour...all getting crappy health care. We won't be taxed that heavily. Now - this debate has gone on since during the campaign - and right after the election, Baucus introduced that policy paper I'm speaking of (read the actual paper here.). If you don't feel like doing that - and I suspect most here won't - here's a news item from The Hill, dated 12 November 2008, the date of the release of his plan: "Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus stepped to the forefront of the national debate over healthcare with a sweeping universal-coverage plan, pushing the issue to the top of the next Congress's agenda. 'In 2009, Congress must take up and act on meaningful health reform legislation that achieves coverage for all Americans while also addressing the underlying problems in our health system,' the Montana Democrat said in a policy paper released Wednesday. 'The urgency of this task has become undeniable.' Under the Montana Democrat's plan, all Americans would be required to hold a health insurance policy, going one step further than President-elect Barack Obama's plan. Individuals could keep their existing health plans or join a nationwide insurance pool to buy coverage, the price tag of which would be reduced with government subsidies. Insurers would not be allowed to discriminate based on pre-existing conditions, a centerpiece of Obama's plan..." "http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/baucus-unveils-sweeping-healthcare-plan-2008-11-12.html" Don't you guys get bored with seeing everything through a partisan political lens? There's a lot more going out here - and you miss the opportunity to get so much more information by doing such a thing. It's always the same old argument. That's tired. Ick...!

content: You're going to tell me you aren't partisan? Oh, well... I'm guessing that, if we have a tax levied against us to pay for this, it will be minimal, but a progressive one. A consideration: If a person can't afford health care on their current salary, and they may be taxed an extra, let's say, $20 a month for them to have the opportunity to have access to basic, quality health care, does it make sense for them to reject a tax increase? Or, do you reject any tax increase on principle alone?

content: quote: Originally posted by mcgreer: You're going to tell me you aren't partisan? Oh, well... A consideration: If a person can't afford health care on their current salary, and they may be taxed an extra, let's say, $20 a month for them to have the opportunity to have access to basic, quality health care, does it make sense for them to reject a tax increase? Or, do you reject any tax increase on principle alone? I'm going to tell you I'm conservative ... and that I'd be making the same argument if it was a Republican president. Now ... a consideration. Assuming you are on TriCare Prime and not yet 65, how would you feel about having Uncle's share of your TriCare Prime coverage added on to your taxable income? How do you think an active duty military family would feel about it? Tell me where you, I, or they are advantaged by Baucus' proposal ... or any other family that already has employer-subsidized health care? As to tax increases ... yeah ... I reject them on principle and will continue to do so until the federal government starts acting in a responsible manner with taxpayer money. Bush's TARP, Pelosi's stimulus bill, and the pork-laden Omnibus bill ... have me in opposition to any tax increase for anything. I've already seen a tax increase under Obama of $700+ this year ... not needing anymore from the man that promised that 95% of Americans would see a reduction or no change.
